def.dt: :of or relating to the people who live in a country civil liberties/duties a period of civil unrest [=a time when groups of people in a country fight one another] see also civil disobedience civil war

:of or relating to the regular business of the people in a city, town, state, etc. :not connected to the military or to a religion They got married in a civil ceremony at city hall. civil institutions
:polite but not friendly :only as polite as a person needs to be in order to not be rude It was hard to be civil when I felt so angry. She was barely civil to me. opposite uncivil
:caring about art, science, government, people's well-being, etc. She argues that a civil [=(more commonly) civilized] society takes care of its weakest members. opposite uncivil

:relating to laws that describe a person's rights rather than to laws about crime The couple filed a civil suit against the company that made the crib. civil cases rules of civil procedure compare criminal 2 see also civil law civil liberty civil rights

utxt.vi: The couple couldn't even discuss things civilly [=politely] anymore.
“Thank you for helping me, sir,” she said civilly.

def.dt: :a group of people who are not part of the military but are trained to protect and help people if an enemy attacks their country or if there is a natural disaster (such as a flood or earthquake) She's in training to be part of the local civil defense. the head of civil defense

:refusal to obey laws as a way of forcing the government to do or change something In an act of civil disobedience, the family sent its tax money to an antiwar organization. A student organization is encouraging civil disobedience as a way to get the university to change its policies.
:a type of engineering that deals with the science of designing and building roads, bridges, large buildings, etc. He has a degree in civil engineering.
:laws that deal with the rights of people rather than with crimes compare criminal law

:the right of people to do or say things that are not illegal without being stopped or interrupted by the government Freedom of speech is a civil liberty. usually plural Opponents said the law would threaten civil liberties.
:a marriage performed by a person (such as a justice of the peace) who is not a religious leader a mayor who has officiated at several civil marriages this year

:the rights that every person should have regardless of his or her sex, race, or religion Martin Luther King, Jr., fought for civil rights. The U.S. civil rights movement achieved equal rights legislation for African-Americans.
:a person who works for the government :a person who works in the civil service

:the part of a government that takes care of the government's basic business :the administrative part of a government often used before another noun a civil service employee the civil service system I took the civil service exam. [=I took a test to get a job in the civil service]
